validation_note: The input data is accurate. Optineurin (OPTN) is an autophagy receptor that mediates the clearance of TDP-43 aggregates. This function is enhanced by TBK1-mediated phosphorylation of OPTN. Mutations in either OPTN or TBK1 are linked to ALS and impair this protective pathway.

functions.cellular_process: Optineurin (OPTN) functions as an autophagy receptor that recognizes and targets ubiquitinated protein aggregates, including those of TDP-43, for clearance. Its efficiency in this process is enhanced by phosphorylation from the kinase TBK1.
functions.effect_description: The OPTN/TBK1 pathway is a crucial component of cellular quality control for removing pathological TDP-43. ALS-causing mutations in OPTN or TBK1 disrupt this autophagic clearance mechanism, leading to the accumulation of toxic TDP-43 aggregates and contributing to motor neuron degeneration.
biological_consequence: TDP-43 aggregation and ubiquitination → TBK1-mediated phosphorylation of OPTN → Enhanced binding of phosphorylated OPTN to ubiquitinated TDP-43 → Recruitment of TDP-43-OPTN complex to autophagosomes → Autophagosome-lysosome fusion and degradation of TDP-43 aggregates → Reduction of cellular toxicity and neurodegeneration
specific_effects: OPTN colocalizes with TDP-43 positive inclusions in motor neurons of ALS patients.
TBK1 phosphorylates autophagy receptors, including Optineurin, which promotes the clearance of protein aggregates.
Mutations in OPTN and TBK1 are genetic causes of ALS and are associated with TDP-43 pathology.
Loss of OPTN leads to TDP-43 mislocalization and aggregation in mouse models.
Overexpression of wild-type OPTN can decrease inclusion bodies formed by truncated TDP-43 via autophagy.

evidence.paper_title: TBK1: a new player in ALS linking autophagy and neuroinflammation
evidence.relevant_quote: In the autophagy pathway, TBK1 phosphorylates autophagy receptors Optineurin and p62 and promotes autophagic clearance of damaged organelles and protein aggregates.
evidence.authors: Oakes JA, Davies MC, Collins MO

evidence.paper_title: Optineurin defects cause TDP43-pathology with autophagic vacuolar formation
evidence.relevant_quote: Our findings suggest that homozygous OPTN deletion or mutations might result in autophagic dysfunction and TAR-DNA binding protein 43 mislocalization, thereby leading to neurodegeneration of motor neurons.
evidence.authors: Ito Y, Miki Y, Hatanaka Y, Taniguchi Y, Yoshizawa T, Mori A, Ayaki T, Ito D, Suzuki N, Takahashi R

evidence.paper_title: Mutations in the ubiquitin-binding domain of OPTN/optineurin interfere with autophagy-mediated degradation of misfolded proteins by a dominant-negative mechanism
evidence.relevant_quote: Overexpression of wild-type (WT) OPTN decreased IBs [inclusion bodies] through K63-linked polyubiquitin-mediated autophagy...[and] decreased the IBs formed by...the truncated form of TARDBP/TDP-43 (TARDBP(ND251)).
evidence.authors: Shen T, Li Y, Wang D, Liu B, Wang F, Li S, Li XJ

evidence.paper_title: Ubiquitin-independent function of optineurin in autophagic clearance of protein aggregates
evidence.relevant_quote: Furthermore, TBK1 regulates protein aggregation by phosphorylating OPTN and also various other proteins involved in the regulation of autophagy.
evidence.authors: Tumbarello DA, Manna PT, Allen M, Bycroft M, Arden SD, Kendrick-Jones J, Buss F

mechanism: Optineurin (OPTN) functions as an autophagy receptor that recognizes and targets ubiquitinated protein aggregates, including those of TDP-43, for clearance. Its efficiency in this process is enhanced by phosphorylation from the kinase TBK1.
effect: The OPTN/TBK1 pathway is a crucial component of cellular quality control for removing pathological TDP-43. ALS-causing mutations in OPTN or TBK1 disrupt this autophagic clearance mechanism, leading to the accumulation of toxic TDP-43 aggregates and contributing to motor neuron degeneration.
summary: TDP43 activates OPTN to modulate autophagic clearance of tdp-43, ultimately affecting reduction of cellular toxicity and neurodegeneration.
